image.altText: Victoria Cafasso and Subaru in bush car park.

items.synopsis: Police say the driver of a car they're now searching for as part of the Victoria Cafasso murder investigation is "a strong person of interest" and was seen veering off down a bush track around the time of the murder in 1995.

title.children: Police divers look for murder weapon, clothes in new Victoria Cafasso cold case search

image.altText: House at Arncliffe

items.synopsis: After an almost 10-hour raid on a Sydney apartment block emergency services have confirmed they found low level radioactive isotopes inside a home.

title.children: Border Force raid on Sydney apartment block finds radioactive material

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The prime minister has indicated he will take part on Friday in what is expected to be the most contentious debate on the floor of Labor's national conference — that surrounding the AUKUS security pact — as the government attempts to quell internal disquiet over the contentious deal with the US and UK.

title.children: Albanese poised to speak at Labor conference in defence of AUKUS

image.altText: Sam Williamson bursts out of the water wearing an Australian gold swimming cap

items.synopsis: Swimming Australia calls a special general meeting to avoid being kicked out of the sport's global governing body due to perceived governance issues.

title.children: Swimming Australia threatened with expulsion from World Aquatics

image.altText: A hazy red sky over federation square full of people

items.synopsis: Melbourne's Federation Square has been axed as a live site for the remainder of the Women's World Cup due to dozens of flares being let off within the capacity crowd there during Wednesday night's semifinal.

title.children: Federation Square axed as Women's World Cup live site

image.altText: A 4WD towing a horse float leans on the side of an embankment with a tow truck nearby.

items.synopsis: The young driver of a car that crashed while towing an unregistered horse float, injuring five people and killing four horses, is charged with driving offences — as several of those involved in the crash battle for compensation.

title.children: Young horse float driver for Ben Yole charged over crash that injured passengers, killed horses

image.altText: Brigid Malone sits at a desk

items.synopsis: Australia's unemployment rate has risen to 3.7 per cent for July, up from 3.5 per cent in June, with 36,000 more people unemployed, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics data.

title.children: Brigid has been looking for a job for months. The latest figures show there are thousands just like her

image.altText: a woman looks directly at the camera. She has long brown hair and is wearing a black top.

items.synopsis: Kobie Parfitt feared for her life days before she was killed by her friend Shannon Jeffrey, the Supreme Court in Melbourne heard today. Jeffrey had only been out of prison for less than two weeks when Ms Parfitt was killed.

title.children: Mother of four killed by friend who dumped body down a mineshaft

image.altText: A young man stands with an older woman in front of microphones.

items.synopsis: Billionaire miner Gina Rinehart threatened her son John Hancock when he tried to find out about what had happened to his inheritance, the WA Supreme Court is told, at a time when he was so hard up for cash he couldn't even afford new brake pads for his car.

title.children: 'Heroic' John Hancock forced to drive with old brake pads amid pressure from billionaire mother, court told

image.altText: Donald Bonney staring off

items.synopsis: A private hydro scheme in Tasmania's north west is capable of powering 800 homes — but questions are being asked about the impact on neighbouring properties.

title.children: 'It's totally wrong': Trees are dying on Donald's property as pastures turn to bogs

image.altText: A crocodile sits on a sandy bank while a man fishes nearby

items.synopsis: A viral online video showing a man fishing near a large croc has left authorities dismayed and locals concerned for the future of the well-known reptile.

title.children: Authorities warn against 'life-threatening risks' after man filmed fishing metres from saltwater crocodile

image.altText: Police arrested a man at Laguna property near Cessnock.

items.synopsis: A New South Wales court hears that the charges against the 75-year-old are "as serious as it gets" and that "he will go to jail" if convicted.

title.children: Bail granted for Hunter Valley man charged with 21 historical child sex offences

image.altText: A young girl in a white sweater with blue, black, pink and purple words looks left of frame.

items.synopsis: Katalina Kovacevich, 5, was born with a rare genetic condition which causes tumours to grow in her brain, and her family has been forced to travel interstate to get treatment for her — a situation the WA Liberals say is "not good enough".

title.children: At 5, Katalina needed life-changing surgery. But her city's hospital could not help

image.altText: A plane with the LATAM Airlines logo flying

items.synopsis: The LATAM Airlines flight was on its way from Miami to Santiago when its captain fell ill, forcing the other two pilots to proceed with an emergency landing.

title.children: Pilot dies after plane makes emergency landing in Panama

image.altText: A dead crocodile with pale skin lies among mangroves on the edge of a river.

items.synopsis: A poaching hook attached to a wired rope was retrieved from inside the 2.6m saltwater crocodile, which was found in the Ross River near Townsville.

title.children: Queensland croc's 'slow, agonising death' was 'deliberate', authorities say

image.altText: Rachel Zegler stands and smiles at a press event.

items.synopsis: Resurfaced comments made by actress Rachel Zegler about her upcoming live-action remake of Disney's Snow White spark outrage online.

title.children: 'The original came out in 1937, and evidently so': Actress Rachel Zegler's Snow White interview goes viral

image.altText: A surgeon standing in a surgery room, working on a pig kidney in a plastic bucket

items.synopsis: A pig's kidney that was transplanted into a brain-dead man by US surgeons has worked normally for over a month, sparking hope the operation could eventually be tried in living patients.

title.children: Pig kidney transplanted into a human body works for over a month

image.altText: An IGA express with fresh produce displayed outside.

items.synopsis: The court saw CCTV footage from the supermarket, showing staff removing use-by and best-before-date stickers and replacing them with new, extended dates.

title.children: Operator of Canberra IGA fined $16,500 for tampering with food item expiry dates

image.altText: bunches of flowers left underneath a powerpole near the site where a teenager was fatally stabbed.

items.synopsis: Crisis support workers are called into to assist a community in mourning following the tragic death of a teenage boy on the New South Wales North Coast.

title.children: Community shares 'shock and heartbreak' after 16yo's alleged stabbing death

image.altText: A smiling young man with a neat beard and spectacles, wearing a graduate's hat.

items.synopsis: Newcastle District Court heard that Kieran Peter Norman, 31, had 17 private music students, most of whom were children, when he was arrested last year.

title.children: Music teacher who groomed 11-year-old avoids jail after loss of career deemed extra punishment

image.altText: Eddie Jones speaks to the media at Sydney Airport.

items.synopsis: Wallabies coach Eddie Jones launches a scathing attack on reporters before his squad fly out of Sydney for the men's Rugby World Cup in France, claiming they are "so bloody negative about everything".

title.children: 'Worst press conference I've ever had': Jones slams media as Wallabies fly out for Rugby World Cup

image.altText: Owen Farrell stands with his hands on his hips

items.synopsis: Rugby union's focus on limiting high tackles has come under the spotlight again after England captain Owen Farrell was handed a reprieve after being sent off against Wales last weekend — a decision one group says "made a mockery" of player welfare, writes Simon Smale.

title.children: England's skipper should have been banned for six weeks, but World Rugby 'critically undermined' its own guidelines

image.altText: A man in a mask sitting on a chair.

items.synopsis: An uprising inspired and led by women was met with a swift crackdown. Now, young dissidents speak to the ABC in a series of interviews conducted in secret.

title.children: 'Friends, it has just started': A hacker in hiding has a message for the world

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green holds her face in her hands with the result on the scoreboard behind

items.synopsis: The Matildas wanted to create their own Cathy Freeman moment. They did — but not in quite the way they expected.

title.children: Matildas' semifinal loss to England was not about the finish, but the run

image.altText: An England player and a Matildas opponent challenge for the ball during the Women's World Cup semifinal.

items.synopsis: The Matildas' 3-1 loss to England creates history by becoming the most-watched TV program since the current audience measurement system began in 2001.

title.children: Matildas' World Cup semifinal sets TV audience record

image.altText: Australia's football superstar Sam Kerr looks sad but gives a thumbs up to the crowd after the Matildas Women's World Cup loss.

items.synopsis: The Matildas call for improved funding for football and urge their plethora of new-found fans to stay on the bandwagon after the Women's World Cup.

title.children: 'Isn't good enough': Sam Kerr, Matildas teammates call for investment, support for football after World Cup run

image.altText: A satellite view of an island in the South China Sea.

items.synopsis: Satellite photos of construction on Triton Island, one of the major islands in the Paracel group that is also claimed by Vietnam and Taiwan, causes speculation a new airstrip is in the works, but analysts say it may be too early to tell.

title.children: 'Everybody take a breath': Questions raised over whether China is building an airstrip on contested island

image.altText: A coat of arms and sign saying 'Local Court' on a column outside a courthouse.

items.synopsis: Neil Marika’s violence towards his partner Miss Yunupiŋu had escalated to a point where he assaulted her "in front of members of the community", the inquest into her death has heard.

title.children: Killer had assaulted partner in public, but community felt 'helpless', coroner hears

image.altText: A close-up of an embryo being surgically prodded

items.synopsis: Affected patients were alerted this week about the contamination at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital's fertility unit.

title.children: Sydney hospital forced to destroy IVF patients' embryos and shut down fertility laboratory

image.altText: A male politican in a blue suit and white tie, speaking at a lecturn in front of a sign that reads 'working for Australia'

items.synopsis: A move by the unions to commit Labor to introduce a tax on "super profits" recorded by banks and other corporations has been watered down.

title.children: Union push for 'super profit tax' to fund housing watered down at Labor conference

image.altText: A phone screen showing a mail app with two notifications

items.synopsis: Phishing is the most commonly reported scam in Australia, with scammers harvesting tens of millions of dollars every year from unsuspecting victims.

title.children: It was the most reported scam in Australia last year. Here's how phishing works

image.altText: A man with dark hair looks serious as he is photographed outside court.

items.synopsis: Prosecutors will again be able to pursue charges against trucking boss Simiona Tuteru, who was in charge of a driver who fatally crashed into four police officers on Melbourne’s Eastern Freeway.

title.children: Boss of truck driver who killed four police officers in Melbourne freeway crash may face new court action

image.altText: A man standing in the middle of a giant museum room with a skylight on the ceiling and artefacts all around the walls

items.synopsis: The museum director said the incident is "highly unusual" and it is working to determine what has been stolen or damaged.

title.children: British Museum fires staff member over missing and stolen items

image.altText: Indigenous man with grey hair and one eye looks into the distance

items.synopsis: Djiniyini Gondarra, a spiritual leader from north-east Arnhem Land, wants to see his decades-long calls for a treaty fulfilled. But he doesn't believe a Voice will deliver it.

title.children: He's been described as Australia's Gandhi. And this civil rights leader is planning to vote No to a Voice

image.altText: A woman and two children walk down a runway with an small plane behind them.

items.synopsis: It's something we rarely hear about in Australia – for good reason – but there are people living in witness protection programs across the nation.

title.children: New name, new history, new location: Is witness protection really like what we see on TV?
